area of specialty: v oice and v oice disorders
description: There are two categories of artificial larynxes  electrolarynx (EL) and pneumatic artificial larynx (PAL).(1) An EL is a handheld, battery-powered  device that vibrates electromechanically.(1,2) The EL is placed against the patient’s neck or inside the patient’s mouth,and electronic vibrations are transformed into words within the oral cavity.(2,3) Pitch and volume settings can be personalized to each patient’s preferences.(2) The EL is the most commonly used method of alaryngeal speech among laryngectomees.(4,5,6) A PAL consists of a vibratory valve inside a plastic tube, with one end placed over the patient’s stoma and the other end inside the patient’s mouth.(1,4) Pulmonary air is directed through the tube,and the vibrations reach the patient’s mouth, where they are transformed into speech(1,4)
indications: An artificial larynx is indicated for a patient who has had his or her larynx removed due to laryngeal cancer or severe trauma(7): the surgery to remove the larynx islaryngectomy.(8,9)Laryngectomee is a person who has undergone laryngectomy(8): following which, a laryngectomee is unable to produce a normal voice.(10) Additionally, the person can no longer breathe through the nose or mouth, and hence breathes via a stoma in the neck(10)
For detailed information on laryngectomy, see Clinical Review…Laryngectomy, Partial ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708836and Clinical Review…Laryngectomy, Total ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708744

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: In what manner did the patient lose his or her larynx? Was this a total or partial laryngectomy to treat cancer? Was this because of trauma?

course of treatment.medical management: Note whether the patient has received or is currently receiving radiation therapy, chemotherapy, or both for cancer
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications physician has prescribed; are they being taken?
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether or not they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether the patient has had occupational, physical therapy, or speech therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Use of the EL might be easier or more difficult depending on factors related to the patient’s underlying diagnosis or any comorbid conditions (e.g., cognitive impairment, arthritis). It is important to consider the time that has elapsed since the patient’s most recent chemotherapy or radiation therapy treatment due to the potential for pain
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms, which can include assessment of secretions and secretion management from stoma, pulmonary function, and changes in smell or taste(10)
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document any other symptoms patient is experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that would need a referral to a physician
history of present illness.respiratory status: The patient might require supplemental oxygen. Does the patient have difficulty breathing through the stoma? Note stomal competency, skin breakdown, or excessive secretions. Does the patient use heat and moisture exchanger (HME)?(10)The laryngectomee population is at significant risk for depression due to grieving the loss of previous life and function.(5,12,13) It is important to assess how well the patient is coping with this significant change and to make referrals to a mental health professional if necessary(13)A patient self-report  inventory that contains 30 statements evaluating a patient’s judgment regarding the impact of the voice disorder on daily activities. past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Has the patient ever used an artificial larynx before? Has the patient used another form of alaryngeal communication such as esophageal speech or tracheoesophageal speech?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask the patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including overthe-counter  drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask the patient about other symptoms he or she is experiencing

If so, is it in good working order? Does the patient wear glasses? Does the patient require a cane or walker?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Document use of assistive or adaptive equipment for communication. Laryngectomees might already be utilizing an alternative method of communication, such as pen and paper(5)
relevant tests and measures.self-care activities of daily living: Is the patient able to care for his or her artificial larynx? Can the patient adequately care for his or her stoma? The patient should use swabs or washcloths daily to wipe the skin around the stoma and the artificial larynx to prevent the crusty buildup of mucus or blood. Some patients who produce a lot of secretions require suctioning devices. Refer the patient to his or her physician and/or occupational therapy if the patient appears to have an excessive buildup of secretions or reports difficulty cleaning the stoma or artificial larynx
relevant tests and measures.oral structure and oral motor function: Complete a full oral motor evaluation to determine strength/function of oral motor mechanism. The articulators (tongue, lips, teeth) need to function normally for a laryngectomee to produce intelligible speech with an artificial larynx(5,8,10,18)
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: It is important to assess cognitive abilities in patients who have undergone laryngectomy to determine the most appropriate voice substitution method.(15) Using an artificial larynx requires patients to manage timing, placement, and exaggerated articulation simultaneously. The Mini-Mental  State Examination (MMSE) is an appropriate assessment tool to screen for arousal, attention, and otherorientation to time, orientation to place, registration, attention and calculation, recall, naming, repetition, comprehension, reading, writing, and drawing(16)

contraindications precautions.general: Following an evaluation of the patient, the SLP and the patient must decide together

assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral should be made to psychology or psychiatry if signs of depression or grieving are noted.(15) In case of stomal stenosis or difficulty breathing, refer the patient to his or her ENT surgeon for revision of the stoma.(17) For patients who have very stiff neck tissue and musculature, resulting in difficulty achieving vibration via the neck, referral to physical therapy might be appropriate
treatment summary: Improving the intelligibility and “acceptability” of artificial larynx speech –In a study conducted in the United States, researchers were able to improve EL speech intelligibility by wrapping a 1-inch thick foam around the EL(19) -Although the foam reduced the EL’s noise interference, it created a larger and more awkward device for the user –A new EL is being developed that uses a force sensor to allow the patient to alter intonation and contrastive stress in conversation(12) –In a study conducted in China of aerodynamic characteristics of laryngectomees, results indicated that the “acceptability” of EL speech according to listener ratings was the highest when patients held their breath while speaking(1) -Laryngectomees who naturally held their breath during the speech had been using the EL for the longest period. Those laryngectomees who did not do this naturally were trained to do so by the researchers(1) –In a case study conducted in France, researchers reported on an implantable artificial larynx. Following total laryngectomy for laryngeal cancer, the permanent tracheal prosthesis was implanted via cervicotomy, and 4 months later a removable portion of the artificial larynx valve system was implanted via endoscopy. The permanent portion of the implantable larynx did not interfere with swallowing, and the patient continued to be able to eat by mouth. The removable portion allowed the patient to speak in a whisper voice when the stoma was occluded manually. The removable portion also caused mild dysphagia, for which therapy was provided(21) ›See Description and Indications of device/equipment and Guidelines for use of device/equipment , above . Initially, finding the best place for either an intraoral artificial larynx or a neck placement EL is accomplished by trial and error(4)
For intraoral devices, generally, the best place is behind the patient’s lips, off of the tongue and to the side of the mouth as not to interfere with articulation(4)
The placement of the EL on the neck differs for each person; generally, the head of the EL is placed on the neck directly below the jaw(19)
The therapist should palpate the patient’s neck to find the most malleable and/or flexible part of the neck that is likely to create the best source of vibration

The neck-placement EL must be held tightly against the neck for optimum energy transfer(19)At first, the therapist might place the artificial larynx before attempting speech; as sessions progress, the patient will start to know where the best vibration is achieved and eventually he or she will place the artificial larynx in the correct position every time without cues or assistanceArtificial larynxes may be used while the patient is an inpatient and as an outpatient at home. The SLP will determine an appropriate home program for artificial larynx use. Eventually, the artificial larynx will be used in all communicative settings  Lack of voice Patient will time the initiation of electrolarynx vibration with start of articulatory movementsPrescription, application of devices and equipment

Poor intelligibility with ELs is often associated with incorrect timing of the vibration. The message is degraded if the vibration starts before the patient begins articulating or continues after the patient stops articulating. This is not usually an issue with PALs because the person’s breath provides the vibration source for speech. The therapist trains the patient to push the button on the EL at the same time as he or she starts moving his or her lips to speak. (**This intervention is based on the author's experience as an SLP practicing in acute and acute rehab settings during 2005-2015)

If the patient has the opportunity to be trained with an EMG- controlled EL, the timing of vibration onset and therefore speech intelligibility may be improved as it creates an articulatory- coordinated voice onset(6) (e.g., the movement of the muscles that initiate articulation also turn on the EL vibratory source)At first, the therapist will demonstrate the timing of the EL by using the device him- or herself. As sessions progress, the patient will become more skillful with the timing of the vibratory source and eventually he or she will start the vibration at the correct time every time without cues or assistanceArtificial larynxes can be used while the patient is an inpatient and as an outpatient at home. The SLP will determine an appropriate home program for artificial larynx use. Eventually, the artificial larynx will be used in all communicative settings  Lack of voice Patient will exaggerate articulation to increase intelligibility of speech with artificial larynx(20)Prescription, application of devices and equipment
Because the vibratory source from artificial larynxes is not as natural sounding as the human voice, exaggerated articulation is required on behalf of the patient to produce intelligible speech(20)
The SLP will educate the patient on how to slow the rate of speech and make appropriately exaggerated articulatory movements(20)

The patient then practices exaggerated articulatory movements in syllables, with word lists, sentences, and eventually conversational speechThe patient learns the articulatory movements with visual, verbal, and placement cues. The patient will master each sound at the syllable, word, sentence, and conversational level with the therapist’s guidanceArtificial larynxes can be used while the patient is an inpatient and as an outpatient at home. Contextual cues have been shown to aid listener comprehension of speech with an artificial larynx;(3) the therapist may train the patient to use gestures, writing, or keywords to improve speech intelligibility

maintenance or prevention: Artificial larynxes must be kept clean to stay in proper working order. Patients who have excessive stomal secretions should clean their artificial larynx devices more often
ELs require battery power; to ensure the EL is working at its optimal capacity, change the batteries per manufacturer guidelines(1,2)
patient education: Laryngectomees can find support and resources, as well as assistance to develop or improve alaryngeal speech, from the International Association of Laryngectomees, https://www.theial.com/
